title: Newtons third law - elephant pushing boxes

content.question: An elephant pushes two heavy boxes across a rough surface. The force that Box <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> exerts on Box <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> is <math alttext="F sub A B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>AB</mtext></msub></math> and the force that Box <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> exerts on Box <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> is <math alttext="F sub B A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>BA</mtext></msub></math>. Which of the following statements indicates the correct reasoning to support the claim that <math alttext="the absolute value of F sub A B, equals the absolute value of F sub B A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>|</mo><mpadded><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>AB</mtext></msub></mpadded><mo>|</mo><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mo>|</mo><mpadded><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>BA</mtext></msub></mpadded><mo>|</mo></mpadded></mpadded></math>?

choices.label: This claim is true only if the boxes are moving with a constant velocity.
This claim is true only if the masses are equal.
This claim is true only if the boxes have equal mass and are moving with a constant velocity.
This claim is true regardless of the type of motion or the relative mass of the object.

content.answer: This claim is true regardless of the type of motion or the relative mass of the object.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
